Title: Body size affects the evolution of eyespots in caterpillars
Authors: Thomas John Hossie, John Skelhorn, Jesse W Breinholt, Akito Y Kawahara, Thomas N Sherratt
Venue: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
Supporting quotes for "Prey species":
- "We examined the distribution of eyespots among final instar caterpillars of known size."
  - "We conducted phylogenetic analyses of hawkmoths in Macroglossinae, the primary subfamily, with extraordinary caterpillar eyespot morphology (20,29), and the most speciose, with more than 800 described species (30)."
  - "Our examination of hawkmoth caterpillar traits revealed that eyespots generally are more common in species whose larvae attain relatively large body size;"
  - "Our phylogenetic analysis clearly demonstrates that the evolution of eyespots is associated with large body size, and our field and laboratory experiments provide an explanation for this;"
  - "Using a phylogenetically controlled analysis of hawkmoth caterpillars, we show that eyespots are associated with large body size."
Reasoning for "Prey species":
- The paper focuses on hawkmoth caterpillars, specifically mentioning the subfamily Macroglossinae, which is known for its caterpillars with eyespots.
- The study uses a phylogenetically controlled analysis of hawkmoth caterpillars to explore the relationship between body size and eyespots.
- The paper does not specify a particular Latin binomial name for a single species but rather discusses the general trend across hawkmoth caterpillars.
- The focus is on the trait of eyespots in hawkmoth caterpillars rather than a specific species.

Title: Deflective effect and the effect of prey detectability on anti-predator function of eyespots
Authors: Adrian Vallin, Marina Dimitrova, Ullasa Kodandaramaiah, Sami Merilaita, D Kemp
Supporting quotes for "Prey species":
- "One example of a conspicuous prey color pattern are eyespots that are commonly found on the wings of Lepidoptera but also in other animals such as mollusks, fish, frogs, and birds (Poulton 1890;Blest 1957;Stevens 2005)."
  - "The deflection hypothesis typically concerns the small eyespots found at the wing margins of many butterflies."
  - "In butterflies, the wing margins tear easily and an attack in this area may offer an opportunity for the butterfly to break free and escape without being severely harmed."
  - "In our first experiment, in which the eyespot was either on the left or on the right "wing" of the triangular prey, we found that the birds more often attacked the side with the eyespot, when the eyespot was small (3 mm)."
  - "In the second experiment, we focused on the intimidation hypothesis, and presented the predators with paired combinations of prey with one large (6 mm) eyespot or two symmetrically placed, smaller (4 mm) eyespots with equal total area as the large eyespot or with no eyespot at all."
  - "Vallin et al. (2007) measured the eyespots of seven peacock butterflies (Inachis io) which elicited a deterring effect on blue tits, and found their diameter to be 6.4±0.5 mm."
Reasoning for "Prey species":
- The paper discusses eyespots commonly found on the wings of Lepidoptera, which includes butterflies and moths.
- The experiments involve artificial prey items with eyespots, not actual living prey species.
- The paper mentions butterflies specifically in the context of the deflection hypothesis and the intimidation hypothesis.
- The mention of "peacock butterflies (Inachis io)" suggests that this species was used as a reference for eyespot size, but it is not explicitly stated that they were used in the experiment.
- The paper does not specify any particular prey species used in the experiment, only that artificial prey items were used to mimic the effects of eyespots.

Supporting quotes for "Prey species":
- "Artificial caterpillars were designed to assess the protective value of eyespots and countershading on caterpillar prey in general; however, for ecological relevance, our prey were modelled loosely on Papilio canadensis."

  - "The entire process was replicated nine times (three times per site, albeit at a different location within site) for a total of 864 artificial prey deployed."

- The paper does not specify any other prey species, so it appears that only Papilio canadensis was used as the basis for the artificial caterpillars.
- The Latin binomial name for the species is provided as Papilio canadensis.

Title: Field experiments on the effectiveness of 'eyespots' as predator deterrents
Authors: Martin Stevens, Elinor Hopkins, William Hinde, Amabel Adcock, Yvonne Connolly, Tom Troscianko, Innes C Cuthill, K T Troscianko
Supporting quotes for "Prey species":
- "Many potential prey species possess features that falsely convey a risk to the predator."
  - "Many animals, most notably diurnal lepidopterans, possess 'eyespots': approximately circular markings composed of colours contrasting with the surrounding body area, and often comprising concentric rings."
  - "The classic experiment investigating how eyespots function, by Blest (1957), showed that birds were startled and clearly alarmed by the display of the (edible to birds) peacock butterfly Inachis io, which involves the sudden exposure of two pairs of eyespots (one on each wing)."
  - "Our field experiments used artificial 'moth' targets (as in Cuthill et al. 2005) with specific patterns, to test the effect on the rate of predation of different types of luminance (brightness) contrast patterns."
  - "The aim of the second experiment was to investigate the effects of different eyespot component arrangements in spots which possess two elements."
  - "The aim of experiment 3 was to determine if there is a difference in the survival value conferred by circular compared to triangular spots."
  - "The aim of the fifth experiment was first, to determine if simple spots consisting of one component would be effective in reducing predation compared to uniform grey control targets (as in experiment 1, but with wing luminance midway between black and white on a linear scale), and compared to targets with spots of two components (as in experiment 4)."
Reasoning for "Prey species":
- The paper discusses the use of artificial "moth" targets, which suggests that the experiments were designed to mimic moth-like patterns.
- The mention of "diurnal lepidopterans" and "peacock butterfly Inachis io" indicates that the study is related to butterflies and moths, but it does not specify a particular species used in the experiments.
- The experiments used artificial targets rather than actual prey species, so there is no specific Latin binomial name of a prey species mentioned in the paper.
- The focus is on the patterns and their effects rather than on specific species.

Title: The position of eyespots and thickened segments influence their protective value to caterpillars
Authors: John Skelhorn, Giles Dorrington, Thomas J Hossie, Thomas N Sherratt
Supporting quotes for "Prey species":
- "Artificial caterpillars were designed to assess whether the position of either eyespots or the thickened body segments associated with the defensive posture, influenced their antipredatory benefit."
  - "We chose to do this for a number of reasons: because eyespots have been found to be more effective deterrents when placed on countershaded caterpillars (Hossie and Sherratt 2012); to maintain a degree of ecological relevance; and so that our findings could be more directly compared with those of Hossie and Sherratt (2013)."
  - "We used the same pastry recipes as Hossie and Sherratt (40 mL of lard, 118 mL of flour, and either 3 drops of Leaf Green food dye in 20 mL of water to produce light green pastry or 6 drops of the same dye in 15 mL of water to produce dark green pastry), and identical ingredients, dyes, and paints (shipped to the United Kingdom from Canada). Countershaded prey with dark dorsal and light ventral sides (4 cm long with a diameter of ≈0.7 cm) was produced by pressing together dark and light pastry cylinders (4 cm long with a diameter of ≈0.5 cm)."

Reasoning for "Prey species":
- The paper discusses the use of artificial caterpillars to study the effect of eyespots and thickened body segments on predator wariness.
- The artificial caterpillars were designed to resemble the late instars of Papilio canadensis and Papilio glaucus caterpillars, as indicated by the use of similar pastry recipes and the mention of countershaded prey.
- The paper does not specify a single Latin binomial name for the prey species used in the experiment, but it implies that the artificial caterpillars were modeled after Papilio species.
